quote_orig: Μόνου γὰρ αὐτοῦ καὶ θεὸς στερίσκεται, ἀγένητα ποιεῖν ἅσσ᾽ ἂν ᾖ πεπραγμένα.
quote_eng: For only this is deprived even from a god, to make undone that has been done.
comment: The object of Choice can only be something that is within one's reach. Changing the past is beyond even a god's power.

quote_orig: Silent enim leges inter arma.
quote_eng: For the laws are silent among arms.
comment: Became a maxim about wartime emergency measures. In its original context, Cicero advocates for armed self-defence.

quote_orig: Πάντα χωρεῖ καὶ οὐδὲν μένει.
quote_eng: Everything flows and nothing stands still.
comment: One of the most famous lines attributed to the pre-Socratic philosopher. Encapsulates a view of a Cosmos that is in constant flux.

quote_orig: Brevis esse laboro, obscurus fio.
quote_eng: I strive to be brief, I become obscure.
comment: One of the cardinal mistakes a poet can commit.

quote_orig: Ὁ κόσμος ἀλλοίωσις, ὁ βίος ὑπόληψις.
quote_eng: The universe is change, life is assumption.
comment: External factors are temporal, internal perception is subjective. Keeping these in mind helps to achieve peace in one's soul.

quote_orig: Τὸ χρεὼν ἐπήρτηται: ἕως ζῇς, ἕως ἔξεστιν, ἀγαθὸς γενοῦ.
quote_eng: Fate hangs above: while you live, while it is possible, become good!
comment: The transience of life frequently appears as an incentive to act in the Meditations.

quote_orig: Ὀρθὸν οὖν εἶναι χρή, οὐχὶ ὀρθούμενον.
quote_eng: Therefore, one should be straight, not straightened.
comment: Expresses the need to be proper and righteous solely by inner volition.

quote_orig: Amor ingenii neminem unquam divitem fecit.
quote_eng: The love of creativity has never made anyone rich.
comment: A poet character's explanation for his poor clothing.

quote_orig: Ipse se nihil scire id unum sciat.
quote_eng: He himself knows only one thing that he knows nothing.
comment: Famous paraphrase of Socrates' views on the limits of knowledge.

quote_orig: Πόσων ἐγὼ χρείαν οὐκ ἔχω.
quote_eng: How many thing I don't have the need for!
attrib_to: Attributed to Socrates by Diogenes Laertius
comment: Socrates seeing the multitude of wares in the market.

quote_orig: Ὁ ἄνθρωπος φύσει πολιτικὸν ζῷον.
quote_eng: The human is by nature a political animal.
comment: According to Aristotle, humans inherently strive to from and live in polities.

quote_orig: Δὶς ἐς τὸν αὐτὸν ποταμὸν οὐκ ἂν ἐμβαίης.
quote_eng: You cannot step into the same river twice.
comment: Possible interpretation: the Cosmos that is in constant flux is never in the same state twice.

quote_orig: Dictum sapienti sat est.
quote_eng: A word is enough for the wise.
comment: The character Sagaristio expressing that no further explanation is needed.

quote_orig: Amicus Plato, sed magis amica veritas.
quote_eng: Plato is a friend, but a greater friend is truth.
comment: Although a pupil and friend of Plato, Aristotle will criticize the theory of Forms, if needed.

quote_orig: Iucundi acti labores.
quote_eng: Pleasant are the labours that have been done.
comment: Cicero argues that memories of past unpleasantness can be pleasant.

quote_orig: Salus populi suprema lex esto.
quote_eng: Let the well-being of the people be the highest law.
comment: Became an often cited—less followed—maxim.

quote_orig: Errare mehercule malo cum Platone… quam cum istis vera sentire.
quote_eng: By Hercules, I prefer to err with Plato... than to come to truths with those people.
comment: I.e. the Pythagorians. An interesting opposition to Arist. Eth. Nic. 1096a.

quote_orig: Μικρὸν ἀπὸ τοῦ ἡλίου μετάστηθι.
quote_eng: Move a little out of the Sun's way.
comment: When Alexander the Great asked Diogenes if he could do anything for him.

quote_orig: Εἰ μὴ Ἀλέξανδρος ἤμην, Διογένης ἂν ἤμην.
quote_eng: If I were not Alexander, I would be Diogenes.
comment: Supposedly said after his encounter with the Cynic.

quote_orig: Ποταμοῖσι τοῖσιν αὐτοῖσιν ἐμϐαίνουσιν, ἕτερα καὶ ἕτερα ὕδατα ἐπιρρεῖ.
quote_eng: On those stepping into the same river, different and different waters flow.
comment: A less paradoxical variation of the more famous river fragment.

quote_orig: Ὁδὸς ἄνω κάτω μία καὶ ὡυτή.
quote_eng: Road up and down is one and the same.
comment: Seemingly paradoxical "unity of opposites", a hallmark of Heraclitus' philosophy.

quote_orig: Αἰὼν παῖς ἐστι παίζων, πεσσεύων· παιδὸς ἡ βασιληίη.
quote_eng: An eon is a child playing, playing draughts. The kingdom is the child's.
comment: Probably the most obscure aphorism attributed to Heraclitus.
